document.docTitle: Iphinoe daphne Mazziotti & Lezzi 2020, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: The cumacean genus Iphinoe (Crustacea: Peracarida) from Italian waters and I. daphne n. sp. from the northwestern Adriatic Sea, Mediterranean

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The cumacean genus Iphinoe (Crustacea: Peracarida) from Italian waters and I. daphne n. sp. from the northwestern Adriatic Sea, Mediterranean

Scale bars: a: 1 mm; b: 300 µm; c: 100 µm; d,g: 200 µm; e,f,h: 500 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Other material examined . 4 adult males, 2 preparatory males, 20 ovigerous females, 11 subadult females, st. 15; 4 adult males, 6 ovigerous females, 4 subadult females, st. 16; 2 adult males, 2 ovigerous females, st. 18; 13 adult males, 9 preparatory males, 46 ovigerous females, 54 subadult females, st.19; 24 adult males, 12 preparatory males, 116 ovigerous females, 76 subadult females, st. 20; 6 adult males, 5 ovigerous females, 11 subadult females, st. 21; 30 adult males, 16 preparatory males, 158 ovigerous females, 65 subadult females, st. 22; 21 adult males, 26 preparatory males, 34 ovigerous females, 130 subadult females, st. 23; 12 adult males, 4 preparatory males, 44 ovigerous females, 22 subadult females, st. 24.
Etymology. The epithet daphne is a noun in apposition. The species is named after the vessel used during the sampling; Daphne is also the name of the first author’s Institute Department.

Diagnosis. Pointed pseudorostrum. Carapace is about twice as long as it is deep and a fifth of the total body length. Ratio CL/CD 2.2. Presence of two perianal setae and one aesthetasc on main flagellum of antenna 1. Adult male with serrated middorsal line and a sternal process tubercle of distinctly bifid apex.

Description of the holotype adult male
( MZB21008 ).
Total length: 4.8 mm .

Antenna 2 longer than body length ( Figure 2A , 3D ). The peduncle has 4 articles; articles 1 to 4 are unarmed; article 5 has rows of sensory setae along anterior margin; flagellum articles bear a single row of setae.
Mandible pars incisiva has 3 teeth, the lacinia mobilis has 3 teeth, there are 11 setae between lacinia mobilis and pars molaris ( Figure 3H ).

Description of the paratype ovigerous female
( MZB21015 ).
Pleonite 6 distally concave, pleotelson rounded with two short terminal setae.

Remarks . This new
Iphinoe
species is similar to other species within the “
I. trispinosa
group” (sensu Ledoyer, 1965 ), in particular
I. armata
,
I. douniae
and
I. trispinosa
. The basis of
I. daphne
’s pereopod 1 is longer than the remaining articles put together, differently from
I. armata
.
I. daphne
differs from
I . trispinosa
in the seta formula of the uropod: 10;5+ 15 in
I. trispinosa
and 12;4+ 9 in
I. daphne .
Pereopod 2 carpus of
I. daphne
presents only 1 plumose seta, whereas there are 3 in
I. douniae
and 2 in
I. armata
. Furthermore, pereopod 2 merus and carpus of
I. daphne
are shorter than in
I. armata ,
as is the merus seta.

An important diagnostic character that distinguishes
I. daphne
from other congeneric species is its sternal process: it has a distinctly bifid apex, whereas this is cup-like with 6–8 serrations in the distal border in
I. armata
. Further differences between these species are shown in synoptic
Table 2.
I
. daphne and
I. serrata
both have a sternal process with a bifid apex. However in
I. serrata
the tubercle is more elongated and the tips of the apex are more divergent.

Distribution and ecology . The species was only recorded in the North Adriatic basin, Area 9 ( Table 4 ), and was not present in samples collected from similar biocenosis (SFBC or VTC) in other areas, thus suggesting that it is a Mediterranean endemic species with a restricted distributional range.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Iphinoe daphne
is typical of soft bottom habitats, from 3 to 15 meters deep. In our samples, this species was found in the “fine well sorted sand” (SFBC) biocenosis (with a sand percentage ranging from 69.7 to 90.6%) and had mean values of organic matter of 0.4%, but it was also found in deeper biocenosis, such as coastal terrigenous mud (VTC), with a silt and clay percentage ranging from 20% to 70% and an average value of organic matter of 1.2%.
